comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
It's hard to tell, but that may be a theodolite on the tripod used for surveying.  Each of the three legs appears to be sitting on a specially preapred surface, not merely the grass lawn.

Maybe that's what Point E is.  A surveying marker point for the Sydney Harbour Bridge construction.

That looks like J.J.C. Bradfield at the far right.

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
Of course, it is a surveying line, for the then proposed construction of the Bridge.  Bradfiled may also be sighted in other surveying photographs taken on that date, 17/03/1925, such as this one approaching Governement House:

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5691840154]

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
Here is a diagram of the surveying Base Lines used to triangulate the centre line for the Sydney Harbour Bridge showing Point E in front of Government House:

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5714059569/]
